articles.title: Why a coronavirus vaccine could take way longer than a year
articles.description: Considering the history and science behind making these drugs, “a year to 18 months would be absolutely unprecedented,” one expert warns.

articles.title: Whale Sharks May Live Up To A Century, Cold War Bomb Dating Reveals
articles.description: The biggest fish in the sea is more vulnerable to extinction than thought, a new study finds.

articles.title: How they flattened the curve during the 1918 Spanish Flu - Nat Geo
articles.description: March 27, 2020 Social distancing isn’t a new idea—it saved thousands of American lives during the last great pandemic. Here's how it worked during the 1918 flu pandemic. • https://www.pnas.org/content/104/18/7582 • https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jama/fullar…

articles.title: 'You Are The Only Passenger': How I Returned To An Empty World
articles.description: Follow a photographer's journey from a remote island in the South Atlantic to a world paused by pandemic.

articles.title: These Photos Capture A World Paused By Coronavirus
articles.description: Stuck at home from New York to Nairobi, National Geographic photographers focus on family, empty streets, and walks in the wild.

articles.title: The Coronavirus Spares Most Kids. These Theories May Help Explain Why
articles.description: Experts weigh in on the biological reasons children could be better protected from severe cases of COVID-19.

articles.title: The Great Lakes Depend On Ice. This Winter, They Barely Froze
articles.description: The region comes alive during winter. But both culture and the economy suffer when the cold doesn't come.

articles.title: Stuck In A Cramped Space? This Astronaut Has Some Advice
articles.description: Chris Cassidy is about to spend six months on the ISS. He knows a thing or two about living in a small space.

articles.title: Into the Unknown: Mawson's Antarctic Trek (2013)
articles.description: They were 31 men at the bottom of the world exploring uncharted territory. What followed was one of the most terrifying survival stories of all time.

articles.title: Fake Animal News Abounds On Social Media As Coronavirus Upends Life
articles.description: As the normally bustling canals of Venice became deserted amid pandemic quarantines, viral social media posts claimed swans and dolphins were returning to the waters. It wasn't true. The canal water, nonetheless, is clearer because of the decrease in boat act…

articles.title: A Chunk Of Yellowstone The Size Of Chicago Has Been 'Pulsing.' Why?
articles.description: An injection of magma under Norris Geyser Basin may be why the region is five inches higher today than it was 20 years ago.

articles.author: Nina Strochlic
articles.title: Typhoid Mary's tragic tale exposed the health impacts of 'super-spreaders'
articles.description: Tracking down the culprit behind an outbreak of typhoid fever in 1900s New York was a breakthrough in how symptom-free carriers can spread sickness.

articles.title: 'Dead Sea Scrolls' at the Museum of the Bible Are All Forgeries
articles.description: Months of testing confirm earlier suspicions that the fragments were made in modern times. What happens next?
For certain professions and communities, public health recommendations are difficult, if not impossible, to follow.

articles.title: How This Invasive Snail Could Save Your Coffee From Destruction
articles.description: An orange trail of poop reveals an unlikely ally against one of coffee's worst threats.
